head.title: Medicare Premiums and Social Security Will Rise

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/Health/Diseases, Conditions, and Health Topics/Medicine and Health

hedline.hl1: Medicare Premiums and Social Security Will Rise

abstract.p: Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in cost of living; Medicare premiums, which are ordinarily deducted from Social Security checks, will rise $4.50 a month, while average Social Security benefit will increase by $29 a month (M)

block.p: Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in the cost of living, the government said today.
The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will be the largest since 1992.
Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in the cost of living, the government said today.
The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will be the largest since 1992.
For retired workers, the average Social Security benefit will increase next year by $29 a month, to $845 a month, from $816.

Medicare premiums, which are ordinarily deducted from Social Security checks, will rise $4.50 a month. The increase may jolt beneficiaries, who have become accustomed to stable premiums in recent years. The monthly premium is now $45.50, just as in 1999. It was $43.80 in 1997 and 1998.

Medicare provides health care for 39 million people who are 65 or older or disabled. The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will raise benefits paid each month to 49.4 million people: 45.2 million in the old age, survivors and disability insurance programs, and 4.2 million with low incomes who receive Supplemental Security Income.

Social Security payments are increased to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. Medicare premiums rise with spending in Part B of Medicare, which covers doctors' services, outpatient hospital care, medical equipment and some home health care.
Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute, said the rise in Medicare premiums came as elderly people faced increases in many health care expenses.

Those costs, Ms. Moon said, include the patient's share of the bill for services covered by Medicare; premiums for private insurance to supplement Medicare, and prescription drugs, which are generally not covered outside a hospital stay.
Taken together, Ms. Moon said, the increase in Medicare premiums and other health care costs would eat up much of the increase in Social Security benefits.

But Thomas R. Saving, an economist at Texas A&M University, said, ''Some Social Security recipients will be better off than they were before because the cost-of-living adjustment overcompensates for the actual rise in prices.''
